Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Photocatalytic extension of short-chain molecules for biomass conversion

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: The project investigates a sustainable process that uses catalytic reactions driven by solar energy to convert biomass to hydrocarbon chemicals. The process uses a new catalytic material that generates small reactive molecules that combine to form larger molecules with 10-20 carbon atoms, like those found in diesel and jet fuels. By using biorenewable feedstocks in combination with solar-driven chemical processing, the project could lay the groundwork for a near-zero greenhouse gas technology for producing fuels and high-value chemicals from biomass. The project includes a novel outreach program that educates high-school students in current science issues and provides opportunities for them to be spokespersons for conveying those issues to the broader public.<br/><br/>Photocatalysis has recently been reported to enable room-temperature dehydrogenative C-C coupling of 2,5-dimethyl furan (2-5 DMF) and 2-methy furan (2-MF) while producing hydrogen simultaneously. However, the process suffers from low conversion and poor selectivity, as well as sensitivity to oxygen. The underpinning mechanism (i.e. the radical species generated from C-H activation of the methyl group would resonate to furan rings and lead to a variety of isomer products) is understood as a key reason for this important deficiency. Recently, one of the investigators has discovered that under photoelectrochemical conditions, Ta3N5 can enable an alternative radical-based pathway that is not only highly efficient but also insensitive to impurities such as H2O or O2 in ambient air. The project will extend those studies to photocatalytic biomass conversion. To that end, detailed understanding of the reaction mechanism is needed. The mechanistic studies will include light-dark experiments, detailed product characterization, and experimentation with various radical generator and acceptor species. Moreover, comparisons will be made between the Ta3N5 utilized as a photoelectrode and as a heterogeneous photocatalyst, with co-catalysts such as platinum included in some cases.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project is to use photocatalysis to convert biomass into molecules and materials that are important for the society.  The main challenge to be addressed is that existing biomass conversion schemes cannot yet meet critical needs of the society.  Two types of chemical reactions have been studied by the project.  In the first type, this project sought to couple common products from lignocellulose decomposition, which are typically molecules with 5 or 6 carbon atoms.  In the second type, the project examined how to more efficiently utilize lignocellulose by exploring a lignin-first approach, which can effectively utilize lignin but without compromising other valuable components such as cellulose and hemicellulose.  The key to this project has been the utilization of light as a direct energy input and, hence, photocatalysis.  In comparison to heating, which is more commonly used in biomass transformation, photocatalysis promises new reactivities and milder reaction conditions.  The net result is better controls over the transformation of biomass derivatives.  More specifically, this project has demonstrated an efficient method to couple lignocellulose-derived 2-MF (methyl furan) and HEO (3-hexene-2,5-dione) based on radical chain reaction.  The project also achieved controlled photocatalytic decomposition of native lignin for the production of recyclable polymers.  

The project provided training opportunities for 2 postdoctoral researchers, 3 graduate students, and 2 undergraduate students.  In collaboration with Waltham School District, the team designed and implemented a summer boot camp, which recruited 11 local students from underrepresented backgrounds for a week-long program.  These students learned the promises of biomass and developed a new understanding on STEM research.
